text: Venezuela after Chavez and the prospects
for change in Latin America I'm Marcus
Mabry for the New York Times Caracas
Bureau Chief William Newman joins me now
now on the phone from Venezuela really
what's the mood there today well it's a
very somber mood this morning we're all
waiting for this funeral procession
that's going to take Chavez from the
military hospital where he died to the
Military Academy where he studied as a
young man or he will lie in state the
thousands of his supporters are are at
the hospital now getting ready to march
along with casket so the city feels very
calm but sort of tense at the same time
because there's a lot of uncertainty
about what's going to happen next here
our Venezuelan is afraid of what happens
next what do they think will happen next
well what is supposed to happen under
the Constitution is that a new election
will be called within 30 days the
expectation is that vice president
Maduro Nicolas Maduro who is Chavez is
hand-picked successor will run the
country until then and run as the
government's candidate against Henrique
Capriles who's one of the opposition
leaders there is you know it seems quite
likely that Maduro will win he has a
tremendous number of advantages although
one never knows and then the question
becomes of course what sort of policies
will he and what was his attitude to the
u.s. be there's been you know some
question will the country moderate
toward the US or not in the short run I
think that the answer is that he is
going more radical we know that he
kicked out a couple of US FSA's
yesterday from the embassy accusing them
of spying so the plate of his radical
base he seems to want get more radical
right now but if he becomes president
after a new election then it's possible
that he might seek to moderate somewhat
the the attitudes for the u.s.
Thank You Willy Thank You Marcos
Michael shifter a close observer of
Venezuela and the president of the
inter-american dialogue
washington-based think tank focusing on
latin america joins me now
michael the big question what happens in
Venezuela after Chavez well look like
the most likely scenario is that a
Chavez government will continue in power
the government is strong then the
candidate will likely be Nicolas Maduro
who's the current vice president the
opposition is very demoralized and very
fragmented so we expect that the the
chunk there will be a continuity in in
in the government over the next couple
of months the question is what happens
later on when the economic problems
really become more serious the Obama
administration have been reaching out to
vice president Maduro what in the hopes
that he would be a moderating influence
his pronouncements about US complicity
in the cancer that that killed the
president in the end suggested maybe
he's not such a moderating influence is
that a correct way to look at it well I
think Maduro is a guy who's going to be
very tough rhetorically publicly and we
saw that yesterday in part that was to
mobilize the base of the of the party of
the Chavez party he needs to show that
he's gonna be faithful to the socialist
Bolivarian revolution after Chavez so
that was for more domestic consumption
but he's a hardliner there's no question
about his close ties to Cuba
but he is somebody who is a union leader
he's he you can talk to him he is
accessible I think he's somebody's gonna
have to look to make deals he doesn't
have Chavez charisma he doesn't have
this command over all the factions
within the government coalition so he's
gonna have to reach out a little bit
I wouldn't expect very warm relations
with the United States but at least we
can open up channels of communication I
think that's a real possibility with
Chavez gone you met you mentioned the
Castros and the Chavez gone and the
Castro's in Cuba set to give up power in
a relatively short time is the error of
the larger-than-life left-wing leader
over in Latin America well I think so I
think that I think these were very
unique circumstances that gave rise to
you Fidel Castro or 1959 and to go
childless in 1999 and and we don't see
any leaders today that are comparable to
that
that really have a broader project
Chavez really had money that he gave out
more than anybody else and he gained a
lot of support throughout the region and
of course of course Fidel Castro because
of the ideological question during
during the Cold War and both of them
standing up to the United States there
are other leaders that are have some
comparable characteristics and features
but none that are kind of command and
have the outsized ambition that both
Fidel Castro and a noogler Chavez had so
I think we're entering into new era
although one can never rule out that
other leaders could emerge but right now
one doesn't see any on the horizon in
Venezuela sitting on a lot of oil so
folks there in Washington will be
watching events really closely how much
can the Obama administration actually
influence what happens well there's
always been the contradiction with the
u.s. Venezuelan relationship that the
relations are very bad politically but
have been good economically and
Venezuela sells a large share of its oil
to the United States the leverage that
the United States really has is not very
great and really what it can do which I
think it should do really is to consult
and work together with Venezuela's
neighbors especially Colombia and Brazil
especially which is the big power and
South America that I think is going to
be influential in the in the future in
Venezuela and the United States has good
relations with both of those countries
so I think that's the way really that it
could be engaged in the situation in
Venezuela which is very very uncertain
and we really don't know what's going to
happen in the coming months for the time
being I think things will be fairly
stable and the US should be expressed
its willingness to open up to Venezuela
perhaps consider having ambassador in
Caracas and the Venezuelans having an
ambassador here in Washington but I
think there shouldn't be any illusions
about forging great close warm
relationships between the two countries
at least this short term mr. shifter
thanks for coming on my pleasure thank
you very much that's all for now I'm
Marcos Mabry for the New York Times
